docs.lead_paragraph: High cholesterol levels may undermine aspirin's protective effects against heart attacks, according to a study from the University of Maryland Medical Center. Aspirin works against heart attacks by making it harder for platelets in the blood to stick together, reducing the chance for a clot to form in a blood vessel and block the circulation.

headline.main: When Aspirin Can't Help a Heart

docs.lead_paragraph: An alarmingly high number of women with heart disease are failing to take medicines known to reduce their risks of heart attacks, according to a study released yesterday. The study, published in The Annals of Internal Medicine, found that although at least 85 percent of the 2,763 women studied should have been taking drugs to lower cholesterol, just about half did so.
docs.abstract: New study finds alarmingly high number of postmenopausal women with heart disease are failing to take medicines known to reduce their risks of heart attacks; finds that at least 85 percent of women studied should have been taking drugs to lower cholesterol, but only half did so; finds virtually all should have been taking preventive doses of aspirin, but only 83 percent did; finds women at highest risk were least likely to use drugs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''My husband and I agreed we wouldn't tell anyone my diagnosis,'' the patient told me. Recently, she had tested positive for the gene associated with Huntington's disease. For several years, she had debated whether to be tested. Her mother, after all, had died of the disease, developing psychosis and slowly losing her bodily control and her mind. And because of Huntington's hereditary nature, the daughter had a 50 percent chance of carrying the gene herself.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert Klitzman article discusses complex issues raised by genetic testing in light of his experiences with patient who has tested postive for gene associated with Huntingon's disease, fatal brain disorder; notes even proposed laws to protect privacy of such data will not protect people from problems that emerge in personal relationships; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Up to half of Americans older than 55 have periodontal disease, a bacterial infection that can create deep pockets in the gum tissue and lead to serious infection and the loss of teeth. The standard care is to cut back the gums, clean the pockets and remove tartar from the enamel below the gum line. In advanced cases, where bacteria have eaten away at the jawbone that anchors the teeth, bone grafts are necessary.

headline.main: Experts Debate the Best Way to Fix Ailing Gums

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether or not boys are harder to raise, they appear to be harder to deliver, according to a new study that found higher rates of Caesarean sections and other complications when boys were born. The study, released on Saturday in BMJ, the journal of the British Medical Association, was conducted at the National Maternity Hospital in Dublin through a review of the records from about 8,000 births, all of them beginning normally.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The American Academy of Pediatrics New Mother's Guide to Breastfeeding,'' edited by Dr. Joan Younger Meek with Sherill Tippins. Bantam Books, $13.95. A century ago, a majority of American women breast-fed their infants, and more than half of all babies were still being breast-fed beyond the first year of life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Safe sex -- the proper and consistent use of condoms to protect against sexually transmitted diseases as well as unwanted pregnancies -- still seems to elude a large percentage of sexually active young adults. A newly published survey of 779 sexually active unmarried women 18 to 24 who were recent condom users revealed that in the previous three months 44 percent had waited too long for the condom to be applied.

headline.main: Fact of Life: Condoms Can Keep Disease at Bay

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Memory Bible: An Innovative Strategy for Keeping Your Brain Young,'' by Dr. Gary Small. Hyperion, $25.95. Milton Berle once summed it up for many of us: ''I have a photographic memory, but once in a while I forget to take off the lens cap.''
docs.snippet: ''The Memory Bible: An Innovative Strategy for Keeping Your Brain Young,'' by Dr. Gary Small. Hyperion, $25.95.    Milton Berle once summed it up for many of us: ''I have a photographic memory, but once in a while I forget to take off the lens cap.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Even young babies can be influenced by emotional messages delivered through a television screen, a new study has found. After watching a videotape of an adult actress reacting to a toy with a show of either negative or positive emotion, year-old infants in the study displayed similar emotions in their interactions with the toy.

headline.main: Babies Pick Up Emotional Clues From TV, Experts Find

docs.abstract: New study finds even young babies can be influenced by emotional messages delivered through television screen; finds year-old infants showed same positive or negative emotions when reacting to toy as did adult actress they saw on television; study adds to increasing evidence that children can distinguish and decode specific social and emotional cues much earlier than scientists once thought; study lead author Dr Donna L Mumme holds it suggests very young children are not oblivious to television programs; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health experts often argue that moderate exercise can cut the risk of disease even if it doesn't help with weight loss. A new study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association shows how.
